titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Chauncey M. Depew papers, 1856-1934 MS2095
titlestmt.author: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

publicationstmt.publisher: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-01-11 11:39:06 -0500.

repository.corpname: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

did.unittitle: Chauncey M. Depew papers
did.abstract: Collection consists of fifty boxes of material documenting Chauncey M. Depew's career in public speaking from approximately 1880-1920. It features many published speeches, handwritten and typescript speeches, and notes, in addition to scrapbooks, memorial books, clippings, and photographs demonstrating Depew's prominence as an orator.

prefercite.head: Preferred citation
prefercite.p: Chauncey M. Depew papers, Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Chauncey M. Depew's widow May Palmer Depew donated this collection to The George Washington University in 1929.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Some material may be copyrighted or restricted. It is the patron's obligation to determine and satisfy copyright or other case restrictions when publishing or otherwise distributing materials found in the collections.

bioghist.head: Historical or Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Chauncey Mitchell Depew (1834-1928) was a prominent railroad executive and U.S. Senator from New York and the namesake of the Chauncey M. Depew Professor of Communication at The George Washington University.

Depew was born in 1834 in Peekskill, New York. He attended Yale College, graduating in 1856 with high honors and was admitted to the bar. Depew first gained fame as an orator while campaigning for Abraham Lincoln in 1860. He then served in the New York State Assembly in 1862-63 as a Republican, and was elected Secretary of State in 1863, a position he held until 1865.

Depew became counsel for the New York Central Railroad in 1875, and later served as its vice president (1883) and president (1885). He resigned as president in 1898, at which time he became chairman of the board of directors of the Vanderbilt system of railroads.

In 1898, Depew was elected to the United States Senate as a Republican from New York and was reelected in 1905, serving until 1911. He was again nominated by the State legislature in 1912, but was defeated.
In 1871, Depew married Elise Ann Hegeman. They had one son, Chauncey Mitchell Depew, born 1879. Elise died in 1893 and Depew married May Palmer in 1901. They had no children.
Chauncey M. Depew died in 1928 in New York City.

After the death of her husband, May Palmer Depew donated $120,000 in 1929 to The George Washington University to establish a department of public speaking in her husband's memory. The Chauncey M. Depew Chair of Public Speaking was dedicated in January 1930; Professor Willard Hayes Yeager was the first appointed to that position. The endowed chair is now known as the Chauncey M. Depew Professor of Communication.

scopecontent.head: Collection Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of fifty boxes of material documenting Chauncey M. Depew's career in public speaking from approximately 1880-1920. It features many published speeches, handwritten and typescript speeches, and notes, in addition to scrapbooks, memorial books, clippings, and photographs demonstrating Depew's prominence as an orator and capturing public reaction to his death. In addition, correspondence in this collection includes letters from Mark Twain, Harry Houdini, John D. Rockefeller, William Vanderbilt, and many U.S. Presidents. In all, these materials provide insight into the politics and the communications techniques of the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries.

While the collection does contain a few letters from the Vanderbilts and some speeches about railroads and legislation, there are no records from Depew's tenure with the New York Central Railroad or from his terms in political office.

arrangement.head: Collection Organization
arrangement.p: Organized into nine series: Correspondence, Speeches and Articles, Scrapbooks, Memorial Books, Newspapers and Clippings, Photographs, Genealogical and Biographical Publications, Awards and Certificates, and Memorabilia.

did.unittitle: Correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of two boxes of correspondence between Chauncey Depew and individuals from his personal and professional life. It includes a small number of letters sent by Depew from 1888 to 1923, but the majority of the correspondence is letters received by Depew.
Other than some mail forwarded to Depew from 1839 and a few early letters, the bulk of the correspondence dates from 1886-1926.

Among the correspondents represented in these files are most of the presidents of the United States of the late nineteenth and early twentieth century. Other notable correspondents include William Vanderbilt, Harry Houdini, Mark Twain, and John D. Rockefeller.

Speeches and articles

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains both published and unpublished speeches and articles written by Depew. Materials are arranged first by format (manuscripts; pamphlets; compilations; and speech fragments, notes and reference material) and then chronologically.

Manuscripts include handwritten and typewritten speeches from 1877-1927. Speeches are listed by title when known, or by the first line when no title is identified. Many of these speeches were published and are also found in the Compilations.
Pamphlets include individual speeches published as small pamphlets. They date from 1877-1910, though one is undated.
Compilations consists of collections of speeches published in booklet and book form. These speeches date from 1890-1918.

Speech fragments, notes and reference material contain portions of manuscripts and notes probably used for speeches. This material is mostly unidentifiable by date or event. If any date or event was given on the copy, that is noted; otherwise the first line identifies each copy. Some have numbered pages, while others do not. All are in folders as received at the time of processing. Most are undated.

Scrapbooks

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of thirty-four scrapbooks kept from 1872-1921, each identified on the exterior by dates and descriptions. Some are in poor condition. The scrapbooks contain clippings of speech transcripts and articles relating to current events and to Depew's public activities and oratory, including some unfavorable reviews. Some scrapbooks also contain clippings of notices relating to Depew's personal life, and some appear to be about topics of interest to him personally.

Memorial books

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of six large volumes of clippings of news articles, editorials, obituaries and eulogies about Chauncey M. Depew. Also included are articles relating to his funeral and estate. The volumes all date from 1928.

Newspapers and clippings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series includes newspapers and clippings relating to Chauncey Depew's public speaking career and to his widow's bequest to The George Washington University after his death.

Speech transcripts dating from 1893-96, both of Depew's speeches and speeches made by others, are arranged chronologically. Clippings related to May Palmer Depew's bequest date from 1929-30 and are arranged alphabetically by the state of the publication's location.

The series also contains some original newspapers in an oversized box, including one copy of The Yale Banner from 1854, when Depew was a student, and some special editions covering events involving Depew.

Photographs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains studio portraits of Depew as well as photographs of him within groups and at events, often where he was speaking. The photographs date from 1863-1923.
Photographs are arranged first by type (Portraits, Groups, Events, Unidentified, and Oversized) and then chronologically.
Some photographs are dated. For others, an approximate date was determined by publication dates of the photo in speech compilations or were estimated from age and dress.

Unusual items include a set of photos of Depew with a child exploring a New York Central Rail Road locomotive (with an accompanying note which makes reference to motion pictures) and a series of snapshots of Depew with "His Excellency," an unidentified Asian man, mounted on black paper.

Genealogical and biographical publications

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: There are two books in this series. One is a published genealogy of Depew and allied lines by William A. Eardeley, and one is a biography written by Willard Hayes Yeager, the first Chauncey M. Depew professor at The George Washington University. The biography includes a number of his speeches, some of which were previously unpublished.

did.unittitle: Genealogical and biographical publications
Chronology and Ancestry of Chauncey M. Depew, with 54 other Allied Families and an Appendix on the Hegeman Ancestry, compiled by William A. Eardeley
Chauncey Mitchell Depew, the Orator, by Willard Hayes Yeager
Awards and certificates

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains a number of oversized certificates of appointment, commission, and membership. It also includes a book Depew received as an award for public speaking while an undergraduate at Yale in 1854 as well as his diploma from Yale College in 1856. Dates range from 1854-1926.

Memorabilia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains memorabilia associated with events in Depew's life, including posters, menus, programs, booklets, postcards, sketches, Yale yearbooks, and a souvenir album of the Republican National Convention of 1892. Items date from 1864-1926.
